fields.Title: Direct Financial Loss
fields.Description:
Prevent Loss due to Financial theft
Prevent Loss due to Theft of IP
Prevent Loss due to Fraud
Prevent Loss due to Sabotage

fields.Title: Reputational Damage
fields.Description:
Prevent Reputational damage due to loss of information (customer information, etc.)
Prevent Reputational damage due to (Perceived) lack of information security

fields.Title: Legal and Regulatory Obligations
fields.Description:
Avoid missed business opportunities due to regulator limitations 
Prevent penalties due to missed regulator requirements

fields.Title: Enable Business
fields.Description:
Assist and enable business to use new channels and methods in order to be competative
Reduce risk by implementing Security Monitoring and Response

fields.Title: Business Continuity
fields.Description:
Early detection of threats to provide business continuity
Prevent business against data loss (deletion)
Prevent outages of critical business services

fields.Title: Strategic and Commercial interests
fields.Description: Damage to strategic and commercial interests, e.g. misleading management information, inefficient operation, disadavantage in negotiations etc.

fields.Title: Reconnaissance
fields.Description: Reconnaissance bla bla

fields.Title: Delivery
fields.Description: Delivery

fields.Title: Exploitation
fields.Description: xx

fields.Title: Port Scanning
fields.Description: Any scanning of ports to determine potential entry points into the organization

fields.Title: Mail probing
fields.Description: Any probing attempt via mail to determine valid user accounts

fields.Title: Fingerprinting
fields.Description: Any attempt to fingerprint devices, systems and applications

fields.Title: (D)DoS
fields.Description: DDOS

fields.Title: Physical Access Compromise
fields.Description: Physical Access Compromise

fields.Title: Blacklisting
fields.Description: Blacklisting

fields.Title: Sabotage / Destruction
fields.Description: Sabotage / Destruction

fields.Title: Policy Violations
fields.Description: Policy Violations

fields.Title: Passive reconnaissance
fields.Description: Reconnaissance activities that are carried out without actively scanning the organization. Mostly through harvesting publically available information

fields.Title: Brute force
fields.Description: Any attempt to brute force accounts on perimeter

fields.Title: Social Engineering
fields.Description: Any suspicious emails or calls attempted at eliciting employees to share organizational information

fields.Title: Social media harvesting
fields.Description: Any attempt to harvest and validate information regarding the organization using social media accounts

fields.Title: Web based malware delivery
fields.Description: Delivery of malware via malicious web pages, including exploit kits

fields.Title: Email based malware delivery
fields.Description: Delivery of malware via email

fields.Title: Physical malware delivery
fields.Description: Delivery of malware via physical means, such as a USB drive

fields.Title: Widespread malware outbreak
fields.Description: This is a use case that may cover other L2 malware related use cases. Reserved for use in case of multiple outbreaks within a short period, possibly across organizational domains or geographic locations

fields.Title: Worm propagation
fields.Description: Delivery of malware through automated propagation mechanisms. Such mechanisms are usually vulnerable protocols allowed within the organization

fields.Title: Delivery of Remote Access Tool
fields.Description: (Attempted) delivery of a remote access tool to a user within the organization

fields.Title: Application whitelist evasion attempt
fields.Description: Any attempts to circumvent application whitelisting controls on end-points

fields.Title: Network-based attack
fields.Description: Network-based attacks aimed at manipulating the information transmitted by the user across the network. This includes session hijacking and MITM attacks

fields.Title: Brute force exploitation attempt
fields.Description: Attempts to break into accounts and systems by performing a password guessing attack

fields.Title: Network intrusion attempt
fields.Description: Any direct intrusion attempt into the network, for example by using exploits against systems in the network. Intrusion attempts can be directed at mail servers, web servers or any other internet-facing servers

fields.Title: Application intrusion attempt
fields.Description: Attempt to exploit a service, possibly resulting in application or service crashes

fields.Title: Installation of Remote Access Tool or similar backdoor
fields.Description: Any attempt (both successful and failed) to install a Remote Access Tool (RAT) onto an end-point

fields.Title: Installation of malware
fields.Description: Attempted installation of malware onto an end-point

fields.Title: Suspicious outbound network communication
fields.Description: Any suspicious network communication to an external destination. This includes C&C traffic, blacklisted resources, unauthenticated proxy requests, wrong DNS servers, malicious payload, new domains, suspicious TLDs, etc.

fields.Title: Covert channel
fields.Description: Special type of suspicious network communication aimed at circumventing existent security measures. Can include privacy services such as TOR or true covert channels, for example in DNS traffic

fields.Title: Data collection
fields.Description: Collection of information from within the network in preparation of data exfiltration. Collection always involves transfer of information to a central location

fields.Title: Data exfiltration
fields.Description: Exfiltration of information to outside the perimeter by attackers. This could be customer information or sensitive corporate information. Exfiltration can be done via the network or via USB drives

fields.Title: Credential theft
fields.Description: Stealing account credential from password databases, plain-text files or network sources. May include passive network sniffing of credentials due to usage of insecure communication protocols

fields.Title: Internal reconnaissance
fields.Description: Internal reconnaissance is carried out by attackers after initial compromise to find systems and information that can be used to perform lateral movement

fields.Title: Lateral movement
fields.Description: Lateral movement is the movement of attackers from the initial compromise to another system. Attackers will try to move to always-on systems that have more network access than the system that was initially compromised

fields.Title: Internal Brute force
fields.Description: This use case is reserved for brute force attacks after initial compromise. This kind of activity supports the attackers in lateral movement

fields.Title: Privilege escalation
fields.Description: Any attempts to obtain higher privileges on the system by the attacker, for example through modification of the account or group

fields.Title: File corruption, encryption and unauthorized access
fields.Description: This activity could be due to a ransomware attack or due to a an attacker in the network either looking for sensitive information or seeking to destroy documents

fields.Title: Account breached
fields.Description: Any indications that an account on a system or application was compromised. This includes pass-the-hash attacks

fields.Title: Installation of persistence mechanism
fields.Description: Persistence mechanisms are used to by the attackers so that they can return to the compromised system at any time. Persistence mechanisms include registry keys and applications run at startup

fields.Title: Database compromise attempt
fields.Description: Any attempts to compromise a database or database account

fields.Title: Detection evasion techniques
fields.Description: Any attempts to remove indications of malicious activity by the attacker himself. This can include sabotage of the target system or removal of audit logs. This also includes other detection evasion techniques

fields.Title: Cloud Service or Account compromise
fields.Description: Any indications that a cloud service (SaaS) or account was compromised and is actively being used to either obtain sensitive information or to move laterally into the company internal perimeter

fields.Title: Usage of remote access tool
fields.Description: Usage of remote access tool on host. These tools are used to remotely access and use the compromised system

fields.Title: Rogue network device or service
fields.Description: A new network device or network service could be introduced into the network for purposes of information gathering and lateral movement. New devices could be virtual machines, while new services include DNS, Proxy and DHCP services

fields.Title: Multiple AO categories
fields.Description: This category is reserved for situations in which a single host . Usually, this category is used by generic anomaly detection tools or security monitoring overlays (e.g. multiple alerts from a single device)

fields.Title: Extortion attempts
fields.Description: Any attempts by attackers to gain financial compensation from the organization by not taking action. Such action may include DDoS attacks or sensitive information disclosure

fields.Title: CEO Fraud
fields.Description: Attempts by criminals to impersonate the organization's CEO or other board-level executive and to have the victim transfer large amounts of money. Usually carried out by sending spoofed email or by business email compromise

fields.Title: Volume DDoS
fields.Description: DDoS attack conducted by directing high volumes of (spoofed) traffic to out organization’s network

fields.Title: Protocol (D)Dos
fields.Description: DDoS attack using protocol anomalies. Some network equipment or firewalls cannot effectively deal with some types of protocol attacks. Most commonly, this results in resource exhaustion

fields.Title: Application (D)DoS
fields.Description: (D)Dos attack conducted by mimicking high volumes of legitimate traffic to our web application servers

fields.Title: Illegal entry into datacenter
fields.Description: Physical access compromise by an attacker into the data center

fields.Title: Illegal entry into office space
fields.Description: Physical access compromise by an attacker into the office space

fields.Title: Mobile device lost or stolen
fields.Description: Mobile device, such as a tablet or a phone lost or stolen

fields.Title: Anomalous access token usage
fields.Description: Any anomalous usage of access tokens, such as entry badges

fields.Title: Physical network access compromise
fields.Description: This is usually placement of a physical rogue device in the network. Such a device could be a wireless access point (WAP) or any other device, including Raspberry pi

fields.Title: IP blacklisting
fields.Description: Note that backlisting may occur from resource abuse, but requires a different response as the entry must be removed from the blacklist as soon as possible to avoid further reputational damage

fields.Title: Mail server blacklisting
fields.Description: Any occasion where an organizational email server was blacklisted, possibly due to sending spam or malicious email

fields.Title: Cyber sabotage
fields.Description: Sabotage or destruction of a system through means of computer. This can be done as part of a cover-up strategy or simply to disrupt business.

fields.Title: Physical sabotage
fields.Description: Physical sabotage of an asset. This is physical damage directly from the attacker, or physical damage as a result of industrial sabotage. In case of ICS, sabotage can lead to physical destruction and thus have safety impact as well.

fields.Title: Defacement
fields.Description: Defacement of (most likely) organizational websites. Usually conducted by hacktivist actors

fields.Title: Illegal content streaming or usage of disallowed web service
fields.Description: This could be copyrighted material, but also includes other illegal categories

fields.Title: Insecure communication protocol
fields.Description: Usage of protocols that are outdated and unsecure. Examples of such protocols are FTP and telnet

fields.Title: Vulnerable system or service
fields.Description: Any vulnerable systems or applications / services that leave the system vulnerable for compromise

fields.Title: Unauthorized process launched
fields.Description: Launch of an unauthorized process. Examples of such processes are psexec, powershell and the command prompt. Also covers unauthorized processes running as a service

fields.Title: Illegal or aberrant application found on host
fields.Description: Any application present on hosts that are not allowed by policy or are quite simply illegal. Examples of such applications are hacking tools and pirated software

fields.Title: Resource abuse
fields.Description: This use case is reserved for situations where systems are being abused, for example for bitcoin mining

fields.Title: Unauthorized use of high-privileged account
fields.Description: Any unauthorized use of accounts with high privileges, such as root accounts on Linux / UNIX and administrator accounts on Windows

fields.Title: Unauthorized modification of technical policy
fields.Description: Unauthorized modification of configuration settings. This can be a compliance issue, where the configuration may result in a hardening baseline deviation. It can also be part of malicious activity

fields.Title: Application
fields.Description: This layer focusses on application security

fields.Title: Operating System
fields.Description: This layer focusses on security within the Operating System

fields.Title: Network
fields.Description: This security layer focusses on network perimeter security

fields.Title: Host based intrusion detection system (HIDS)
fields.Description: A host-based intrusion detection system (HIDS) is an intrusion detection system that is capable of monitoring and analyzing the internals of a computing system as well as the network packets on its network interfaces.

fields.Title: Network intrusion detection systems (NIDS)
fields.Description: Network intrusion detection systems (NIDS) are placed at a strategic point or points within the network to monitor traffic to and from all devices on the network. It performs an analysis of passing traffic on the entire subnet.

fields.Title: Security information and event management (SIEM)
fields.Description: Secuirty Contols defined within the Security information and event management (SIEM) system.

fields.Title: Threat Intelligence (TIP)
fields.Description: Security Controls based on Threat Intelligence briefings, such as fingerprint, hashes etc.

fields.Title: End Point Protection (EPP)
fields.Description: Software running on end point capable of detecting/preventing malicious code execution and/or malicious activities

fields.Title: Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
fields.Description: In computer security, a DMZ or demilitarized zone (sometimes referred to as a perimeter network) is a physical or logical subnetwork that contains and exposes an organization's external-facing services to an untrusted network, usually a larger network such as the Internet.

fields.Title: Office Network
fields.Description: Describes the network used for office communications.

fields.Title: Backend Infrastructure
fields.Description: Logical environment which contains the backend servers

fields.Title: Domestic Wide Area Network (DWAN)
fields.Description: Domestic Wide Area Network (DWAN)

fields.Title: International Wide Area Network (IWAN)
fields.Description: International Wide Area Network (IWAN)
